Patient Note: A 72-year-old male with leukemia was brought to the hospital for urgent evaluation after experiencing several days of progressive fatigue, mild shortness of breath, and lower abdominal discomfort. He appeared mildly flushed on arrival, with a body temperature of 37.5°C and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Due to the concerning nature of his presentation, he was rapidly admitted to the intensive care unit and underwent prompt assessment. His initial blood pressure measurements showed systolic readings at 120 mm Hg and diastolic readings around 64 mm Hg. Further examination revealed that his heartbeat was regular, averaging approximately 88 beats per minute. He denied any recent episodes of confusion or altered sensorium, and his neurological evaluation was consistent with a Glasgow Coma Score of 15 that reflected full alertness. His arterial blood gas analysis indicated a pH of 7.42, suggesting no major acid-base disturbance at this time, although there remained a heightened concern for potential clinical changes given his risk profile. The fraction of inspired oxygen he required on admission was around 45%, and his measured partial pressure of oxygen was approximately 72 mm Hg, reported in the context of his ongoing respiratory complaints. Laboratory studies performed shortly after arrival showed a sodium concentration of 136 mEq/L and a potassium concentration of 4.3 mEq/L, which were within acceptable limits. However, his serum creatinine level was elevated at 1.8 mg/dL, necessitating careful monitoring of his renal function. Despite this elevated level, there was no immediate concern for acute kidney injury on top of this finding, and he did not manifest signs of significant fluid overload or severe acid-base derangements. His hematocrit was measured at 34%, which was slightly reduced but not acutely critical, and his white blood cell count reached around 12,800 per cubic millimeter, raising the possibility of an infectious or inflammatory process given his background and presenting symptoms. He maintained full orientation according to clinical observation, with preserved verbal and motor responses consistent with a normal level of alertness. Owing to the acuity of his presentation, he underwent an emergent exploratory procedure for a suspected intra-abdominal source of infection or complication, and he was closely observed in the postoperative and critical care setting because of his predisposition to severe infections. Prior medical history included issues that compromise his overall immune defense, so heightened surveillance and aggressive prophylactic measures were implemented. Throughout the initial hours after intervention, he received supportive care while monitoring his respiratory parameters and hemodynamic stability. Additional imaging was obtained to clarify the etiology of his symptoms, and cultures were taken to identify any possible pathogens. Discussion among the care team emphasized vigilance for potential complications, including careful fluid balance and reassessment of his renal parameters. As the hours progressed, he remained hemodynamically stable with no new signs of deteriorating consciousness, and his temperature remained near baseline without further fever spikes. Plans for ongoing management included tailored antimicrobial therapy once specific organisms were identified, potential adjustment of his oxygen requirements if his lung function changed, and continued evaluation of his creatinine level to ensure there was no worsening of renal status. Throughout his stay, detailed monitoring of his laboratory values and clinical status was prioritized, given his significant risk factors and the emergent nature of his presentation.

Patient Note: A 74-year-old male was brought to the intensive care unit with a high fever, respiratory difficulty, and marked lethargy that raised immediate concerns about a serious ongoing process. He had a known vulnerability regarding his body’s defense mechanisms, placing him at risk for severe complications, and he had recently undergone an operative intervention that had been arranged in advance rather than on short notice, arriving in the ICU in the immediate postoperative period. His Glasgow Coma Score was calculated at 4. His family reported that he had been progressively more tired and confused over the previous day, culminating in an acute decline prompting emergency transport. Vital sign measurements at presentation showed a high body temperature of 39.2 °C, correlating with his flushed skin and possible infectious or inflammatory process. His pulse was recorded at about 89 beats per minute, relatively stable but concerning in the context of the other findings, and his respiratory rate was 26 breaths per minute, reflecting an increased workload of breathing. Measurement of arterial pressures yielded a systolic reading of 128 mm Hg and diastolic of 71 mm Hg. Though these blood pressure indices did not indicate frank shock, they demanded close monitoring given his precarious clinical state. Blood tests drawn immediately revealed a serum sodium of 147 mEq/L and potassium of 4.8 mEq/L, suggesting that some electrolytes were at the higher end of normal ranges and warranting repeated checks to detect any further derangements. Of greater concern was the markedly elevated creatinine level measured at 2.6 mg/dL; this indicated a deterioration of renal function in the absence of any documented longstanding kidney disease. His hematocrit was reduced to 29 %, potentially reflecting either chronic anemia or an acute drop that might impair oxygen-carrying capacity and limit the body’s physiologic reserves. Further laboratory data showed that his total white blood cell population was around 10,400 cells/mm³, a mild elevation that could signal an infectious process or another inflammatory trigger. His arterial blood sample exhibited a pH of 7.46, suggesting a mild shift toward alkalinity or a compensated state that could change quickly depending on ongoing metabolic or respiratory stresses. On arrival, he was placed on a markedly increased FiO2 at 80 %, well above half of the inhaled air, to maintain adequate oxygenation. Despite this high supplemental oxygen, his calculated alveolar–arterial oxygen gradient was markedly elevated at about 220 mm Hg, indicating a significant impairment in gas exchange. Clinically, he appeared tachypneic and demonstrated labored inhalations, with accessory muscle recruitment evident on inspection. He had no documented history of chronically reduced kidney function, and conversations with relatives indicated that he had not faced kidney-related admissions in the past, suggesting a new onset for his current renal issue. Given his severe mental status changes, the team worried about the risk of airway compromise or inability to guard the airway should his neurologic function worsen. At the same time, care had to be taken to evaluate potential causes of his elevated temperature, which ranged beyond typical low-grade readings. Because of the level of sedation required to keep him comfortable and safe for further investigations, the team recognized the urgency in ruling out primary infections and other acute problems, particularly in light of his inherent predisposition to complications from infectious agents or organ insults. Plans were considered for imaging studies to identify possible sources of infection, bleeding, or other triggers for abrupt decompensation, while also evaluating for potential complications related to his recent surgery rather than planning any new operative procedure at that time. By the time he underwent initial laboratory and clinical evaluations, he remained in a state of severely impaired consciousness, and his breathing dynamics signaled the possibility of impending respiratory compromise if interventions were delayed. The clinical picture suggested a complex interplay of high fever, acute renal derangement, and disordered mentation, all superimposed on a background of increased susceptibility to severe illness. Ongoing discussions among the critical care team centered on stabilizing him hemodynamically, preventing further organ dysfunction, and determining whether additional operative management would be necessary after his recent elective procedure or whether more extensive stabilization measures needed to precede any further intervention. His condition at the bedside underscored the delicate balance of supporting his circulation, protecting against the risk of worsening kidney injury, and identifying any treatable source of fever. Despite the absence of a known chronic kidney process, the elevated creatinine on arrival emphasized the need for meticulous oversight, including repeated checks of his urine output and the potential for renal imaging if indicated. Throughout this initial assessment, it was evident that further deterioration in vital parameters could precipitate significant danger for a patient with such weakened baseline defenses, reinforcing the necessity of prompt diagnostics and possible interventions.

Patient Note: A 70-year-old individual with a known vulnerability that compromises the body’s defenses was transferred to the intensive care unit from the emergency department following several days of general malaise, reduced appetite, and progressive confusion. A formal assessment revealed a Glasgow Coma Score of 5. The initial temperature measurement was 36.8°C, suggesting that fever was not contributing to the presentation at that point, and cardiovascular assessments showed a systolic pressure of 124 mm Hg coupled with a diastolic pressure of 69 mm Hg. The heart rate registered at approximately 84 beats per minute, reflecting a relatively stable rhythm, and the respiratory rate was 14 breaths per minute with unlabored breathing, indicating no overt signs of increased respiratory effort at that time. Laboratory values painted a picture of mild deviations, including a serum sodium level of 144 mEq/L and a serum potassium level of 4.6 mEq/L, both of which were within broadly acceptable limits. Some degree of renal insufficiency prompted concern, as the serum creatinine measured of 2.0 mg/dL, indicative of acute renal failure. Hematologic findings offered further insight, with the hematocrit close to 41% and a white blood cell count of 11,400 per cubic millimeter, hinting at a mild elevation suggestive of possible infection or inflammation. Additional investigation into the acid-base status showed an arterial pH of 7.43, implying near-normal balance in the absence of overt metabolic or respiratory derangements. By the time the arterial blood gas was analyzed, the individual was breathing under ambient conditions, so the fraction of inspired oxygen was only that found in room air at 21%. Despite the minimal external respiratory support, the arterial oxygen tension held steady at 75 mm Hg, which did not raise concern for significant gas-exchange impairment. Nonetheless, the patient’s dangerously decreased awareness level raised alarms, as the mental status evaluation suggested a pattern of profound disorientation and an inability to communicate consistently. This profound alteration was a striking feature, especially in a setting where defenses against infections or other stressors are suspected to be less robust than normal. Although the admission was prompted by concerns of rapid clinical decline in the context of immune vulnerability, there was no intention to undertake a procedure that involved opening a body cavity or relying on invasive operative strategies; rather, the approach at this juncture was to evaluate comprehensively for potential sources of deterioration, to stabilize organ function, and to ensure that any significant complications, whether infectious or inflammatory, were addressed immediately. Prior to this episode, the patient had not been known to have chronic dysfunction of the kidneys, and there were no records of frequent hemodialysis or an ongoing requirement for renal replacement therapies. Close neurological observation was carried out, considering the low responsiveness that placed the individual at a high risk for airway compromise and other complications unless carefully managed. Subsequent imaging studies, blood cultures, and specialist consultations were all under consideration as part of the initial workup. The decision to refrain from pursuing any invasive surgical route was based on the patient’s background, the lack of localizing signs that would point to a lesion needing operative intervention, and the immediate need to focus on controlling possible infection, ensuring stable hemodynamics, and improving the severely impaired level of consciousness. Throughout the assessment process, there was an emphasis on vigilant monitoring of vital signs, periodic reevaluation of the patient’s neuro status, and stringent hygienic measures to guard against hospital-acquired complications, especially given the compromised state of the immune system. All these findings reflected the patient’s baseline condition upon presentation, well before any targeted therapies or advanced interventions had been initiated, underscoring the importance of timely evaluation and ongoing supportive care for an individual whose physiologic reserves might be less capable of containing even minor insults without rapid deterioration.

Patient Note: A 75-year-old female arrived at the emergency department describing four days of progressive respiratory discomfort that worsened considerably in the last 24 hours. She reported having felt slightly chilled on and off, yet only noted a mild elevation in her temperature when she checked it at home, which was confirmed on arrival as moderately above her usual baseline, though not strikingly high at 37.6 degrees Celsius. She indicated that her coughing, which began as an intermittent irritation, gradually intensified and was now accompanied by minimal sputum production. Though she did not appear confused or disoriented during the interview, she mentioned being more fatigued than usual, finding simple household activities taxing. She has resided independently for many years, taking care of her daily needs without ongoing assistance, and specifically noted living in her own house rather than a supervised environment. She claimed no further limitations except for occasionally reduced stamina related to a neurological event in her past, which she said caused transient weakness and difficulty with coordination several years earlier. According to her recollection, careful management and rehabilitation helped her regain much of her functionality, but she still routinely follows up with her physician to ensure there are no late complications. She also recalled a longstanding concern involving her liver that once led her to attend specialized evaluations, though she did not elaborate extensively on the details aside from stating that she has to be mindful of potential side effects when prescribed new medications. She denied significant cardiac difficulties that would require regular attention for fluid management and has experienced no episodes of fluid accumulation in her extremities or lungs that might point to a chronic heart condition; she insisted her heart rate fluctuations are typically mild. On examination, she was alert, cooperative, and oriented to time, place, and situation, with no lapse in her current mental clarity. Her breathing, however, caught the attention of the clinical team, given that her rate of inspirations was measured at 15 per minute, which was within an acceptable range but did not match the degree of subjective discomfort she reported. Her pulse was notably elevated at 105 beats per minute, though its rhythm was regular. Documentation of her systolic blood pressure revealed a value of 114 mm Hg, consistent with a mildly reduced level for her typical readings but not acutely alarming. Laboratory results obtained prior to any intervention provided further insight into her presentation. A test gauging her systemic acid-base status returned a reading of 7.32, suggesting a shift toward acidity that merited continued observation and possible additional studies to determine the cause. Her oxygenation status, measured in an arterial sample, showed a partial pressure of 74 mm Hg, which aligned with her subjective complaints of difficulty taking a full breath and feeling winded after minimal exertion. A renal function indicator remained within a reasonable range at 17 mg/dL, and she experienced no known deficits in her kidney output or filtration capacity, stating that her urine production and serum chemistry have generally stayed stable at her routine checkups. An electrolyte panel signaled that her serum sodium was on the higher end, with a measurement of 148 mEq/L, prompting the team to consider her hydration status and dietary intake. Additional labs revealed that her red blood cell concentration was at 50%, a figure that did not appear to compromise her oxygen-carrying capacity, and her serum glucose reading of 114 mg/dL appeared mildly above average but not indicative of a significant metabolic disturbance.nRadiographic imaging of her thorax displayed evidence of infection, along with a collection of fluid located around one lung field, which was consistent with the findings of dullness to percussion and altered breath sounds on physical examination. This fluid accumulation raised the possibility of complications related to her acute presentation, though she did not endorse any known chronic processes that typically result in recurrent fluid build-up in the pleural space. She recalled no abrupt changes to her usual patterns of activity besides progressive shortness of breath over the past several days, indicating that she continued performing the majority of her daily routines before feeling forced to seek medical attention for this escalating respiratory distress. She reiterated that she had no recent hospital admissions or major interventions, and her prior physician visits revolved around regular follow-up evaluations of her past neurological issue and intermittent monitoring of her liver status. Despite the significant respiratory findings, she did not exhibit confusion, speech difficulties, or notable lapses in memory during evaluation, steadily maintaining awareness of her situation. Given her advanced age and the multiple considerations posed by her past medical history, the clinical team determined that her symptoms, exam findings, and laboratory results warranted further in-hospital workup. Her stable but not entirely reassuring vital signs were taken into account before deciding on any acute therapy, ensuring that every relevant baseline measure was documented and understood prior to initiating treatment.

Patient Note: A 67-year-old male arrived at the emergency department reporting several days of worsening cough, mounting fatigue, and a high fever that he first noted upon waking the previous morning. He stated that his cough, initially nonproductive with mild throat irritation, had evolved into a deeper, more distressing pattern over the last day or so, and he began to experience chills and consistent warmth to the touch. At presentation, he was alert and engaged, conversing readily without any signs of confusion or mental cloudiness. According to him, he lives independently in a single-story residence and has not required ongoing skilled care or around-the-clock supervision. He recalls a neurological event several years ago that temporarily affected his speech and coordination, though he says he eventually recovered with rehabilitative support. He also mentions that he has required periodic evaluations for a medical condition tied to certain aspects of his metabolism, though he reports having remained stable in recent times with no major flare-ups. Nevertheless, he became concerned when his current symptoms failed to improve with usual home measures such as rest and oral hydration. On evaluation, his core temperature was measured at 38.9 degrees Celsius, reflecting a significant fever consistent with the abrupt onset of his symptoms. Physical assessment showed that he was breathing at a rate of about 17 breaths per minute and maintaining a heart rate of approximately 100 beats per minute, which he acknowledged felt faster than normal for him when he attempted mild activity. His blood pressure was recorded as 135 mm Hg on the systolic reading, aligning with a stable circulatory status for someone of his age. He displayed no outward evidence of fluid accumulation in his lower extremities or jugular venous distension, and he denied any chest pain beyond the occasional discomfort from deep coughing. When asked about his general medical history, he stated he had been followed intermittently over the years for a significant but well-controlled liver-related condition, which had not necessitated recent hospital admissions. Initial laboratory results showed a mild disturbance in his acid-base balance, with a pH documented at 7.46, though his clinical examination did not suggest any overt respiratory or metabolic compromise. He was found to have a partial pressure of oxygen of 87 mm Hg on room air, confirming that his oxygen level was somewhat lower than desired for an individual without known chronic lung issues. Additional lab testing highlighted an elevated blood urea measurement of 31 mg/dL, raising suspicion that he might be experiencing increased protein breakdown or a reduced intravascular volume status, which could complicate recovery. His serum sodium concentration was noted to be 132 mEq/L, just below normal limits, which, in conjunction with his ongoing fever and reduced oral intake, could signify evolving electrolyte fluctuations. A hematocrit value of 33% indicated a borderline low red cell volume, though he reported no significant dizziness or lightheadedness beyond what he assumed stemmed from feeling feverish. His measured glucose of 128 mg/dL was slightly above his baseline, which he attributed to decreased appetite and occasional sugary sports drinks he consumed to stay hydrated when his cough worsened. Chest auscultation revealed coarse breath sounds over the right lateral lung fields, and imaging confirmed findings of inflammation and fluid layering within the thoracic cavity, consistent with a localized infectious process and excess fluid accumulation. Despite his evident infection and the presence of fluid in the pleural space, he remained oriented throughout the conversation, recounting details about his daily activities and stressing that he has never relied on institutional living arrangements. The team acknowledged that his prior neurological history and ongoing liver-related concerns, though not actively flaring, could affect his overall resilience. With that in mind, he was prepared for further evaluation and management directed at controlling his acute condition, including monitoring of his oxygen levels, repeating relevant laboratory analyses, and ensuring any unstable parameters were addressed without delay.

Calculator Name: PSI Score: Pneumonia Severity Index for CAP
Patient Note: A 68-year-old male presented to the emergency department after three days of progressive shortness of breath, productive cough, and generalized malaise. He noted an intermittent fever at home, which worsened on the day of admission, along with chills and night sweats. He has been feeling more fatigued than usual, struggling to complete his routine morning walks without pausing to catch his breath, and has also experienced mild chest tightness upon exertion. On initial evaluation, he was awake, alert, and oriented, conversing clearly without lapses in memory or concentration. He denied experiencing any acute episodes of unilateral weakness, facial droop, or slurred speech in the past, and he reported no longstanding liver problems. According to him, fluid overload symptoms such as progressive leg swelling, difficulty breathing while lying flat, or episodes of nighttime coughing have not been issues. He described a past difficulty with kidney function, requiring follow-up with specialists, and also revealed a remotest history of a malignant growth for which he received treatment several years ago. On further questioning, he stated that his usual medications include those needed to monitor both his chronic conditions and his past oncologic management, although he did not recall any medication specifically for significantly compromised cardiac output. He claimed that he has never been told he suffered from sudden neurologic attacks or blood supply problems to his brain and had not visited any facility for such concerns. He reported no sign of abdominal issues, and he had never been diagnosed with disorders that would impair liver enzymes or clotting factors. Recent activity levels have diminished because of his respiratory discomfort, which he first attributed to a seasonal change. However, with the escalation of his breathing difficulties and fever, he became worried. Despite staying hydrated, he felt persistently thirsty, and routine checks at home indicated elevated fingerstick readings, prompting him to mention prior abnormal glucose measurements to medical providers. On arrival, his vital signs showed a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and a systolic blood pressure of 140 mm Hg. His core temperature measured 101.3 degrees Fahrenheit, aligning with his complaint of fever. An arterial blood sample revealed a partial pressure of oxygen of 75 mm Hg, consistent with his labored breathing, and his serum chemistry was notable for a blood urea nitrogen level of 30 mg/dL. Further evaluation indicated that his serum sodium concentration was 136 mEq/L, and an arterial blood gas analysis showed a pH of 7.38. His hematocrit was 35%, suggesting a mild decrease in red blood cell concentration, and a random glucose test was 158 mg/dL, confirming the elevation he had suspected at home. Although he endorsed a history of kidney issues, he described meticulous monitoring of his fluid intake and ongoing consultations with specialists. He also confirmed that his previous cancer treatment had gone well, with no recent reactivations or complications, yet he undergoes periodic surveillance. There were no remarkable findings on examination that suggested significant fluid accumulation in his legs or lungs beyond what might be expected with an infection. He did not require continuous supplemental oxygen therapy at home, so the noted hypoxemia was new for him. Nonetheless, he remained conversational, followed commands appropriately, and displayed no confusion. The physical exam revealed inspiratory crackles over a focused region on one lung field, in keeping with his complaints of cough and breathlessness. After calmly recounting his symptoms and history, he awaited further imaging and laboratory assessment to clarify the etiology of his pneumonia and guide management.

Patient Note:
An 85-year-old female with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency room for progressively altered mental status and difficulty walking. She was increasingly lethargic and was less interactive with family for 3 weeks before presentation. She also had urinary incontinence and gait instability for the same period.
Accompanying family reported a fall 3 weeks before admission with significant facial bruising. A computed tomography (CT) scan without contrast posttrauma was reported to have central nervous system (CNS) atherosclerosis with ventricular dilatation that was out of proportion to the degree of cortical atrophy []. A working diagnosis of NPH was made and she was scheduled to see a neurosurgeon for further management.
On admission, the patient had flat affect and poor cooperation. There was no papilledema. She was unable to follow commands for a complete neurological examination. Serum chemistry revealed sodium - 142 mmol/L, potassium - 2.9 mmol/L, HCO3 - 25 mmol/L, chloride - 102 mmol/L, glucose - 298 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen - 21 mg/dL, and creatinine - 0.7 mg/dL. Magnetic resonance scan of the brain revealed subtle debris layering the occipital horns of the lateral ventricles without restricted diffusion, consistent with either intraventricular hemorrhage or pus [Figures and ].
She was febrile to 103°F. Blood and respiratory cultures were obtained and she was started on a broad-spectrum coverage for possible meningitis. She developed diabetic ketoacidosis, which was addressed. She had two episodes of seizure-like activity. A lumbar puncture was initially deferred, whereas NPH had remained the most probable diagnosis, and the patient had a high international normalized ratio (INR). It was performed emergently following clinical deterioration, with development of fever.
The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collected had increased protein, decreased glucose, and mononuclear pleocytosis. It was subjected to Gram-stain, which showed yeast and the species of the yeast were confirmed to be C. neoformans on culture. India ink preparation of the CSF was positive for Cryptococcus along with a positive cryptococcal antigen test. The patient was dozed with intravenous liposomal amphotericin B and oral flucytosine. HIV test was negative.
The patient continued to deteriorate further and had a cardiac arrest on the same day. She underwent cardiopulmonary resuscitation but could not be revived. Blood culture bottles subsequently grew C. neoformans.
Question: What is the patient's serum osmolality in terms of mOsm/kg? You may take the alcohol content as 0 mg/dL. You should use the patient's medical values and health status when they were first admitted to the hospital prior to any treatment.
Ground Truth Explanation:
The formula for computing serum osmolality is 2 * Na + (BUN / 2.8) + (glucose / 18), where Na is the concentration of sodium in mmol/L, the concentration of BUN is in mg/dL, and the concentration of glucose is in mg/dL.
The concentration of sodium is 142.0 mmol/L. 
The concentration of bun is 21.0 mg/dL. 
The concentration of glucose is 298.0 mg/dL. 
Plugging these values into the equation, we get 2 * 142.0 + (21.0 / 2.8) + (21.0 / 18) = 308.05556 mmol/L.The patient's calculated serum osmolality concentration is 308.05556 mmol/L. This is equalivalent to 308.05556 mOsm/kg.

Patient Note:
We present the case of a 45-year-old gentleman, known diabetic for 6 years on metformin 1 g, twice a day, with reasonable control (hemoglobin A1c 6.4%). He was admitted to our emergency feeling unwell with 2 days’ history of vomiting and watery diarrhea, also associated crampy periumbilical pain. He denied a history of similar complaints in his companions, no change in his dietary habits preceding symptoms’ onset. He drinks alcohol occasionally; the last drink was 6 months before the presentation—no illicit drug use history. The initial vital signs were normal. Soon later, he became tachycardic with heart rate reaching 120 bpm, blood pressure 127/70 mmHg, and a normal temperature. He looked dehydrated; otherwise, his examination was unremarkable.
Laboratory workup was significant for initially low glucose 2.5 mmol/L (3.3–5.5 mmol/L), high serum creatinine 632 μmol/L (62–106 umol/L), and high blood urea nitrogen of 21 mmol/L (2.8–8 mmol/L). Serum electrolytes were as follows: potassium (K+) 6.3 mmol/L (3.5–5.1 mmol/L), sodium (NA) 144 mmol/L (135–145mmol/L), bicarbonate (HCO3) 5.8 mmol/L (23–29 mmol/L), and serum chloride 99 mmol/L (99–107 mmol/L). Serum aminotransferases were normal (ALT 31 U/L, AST 27 U/L). He had significant high AG metabolic acidosis with PH of 6.8 (7.35–7.45) and AG of 40, lactic acid (LA) strikingly high reaching up to 24 mmol/L (0.5–2.2 mmol/L). Toxicology screening, including serum ethanol, acetaminophen, salicylate, and urine for oxalate crystal, was negative.
Acidosis failed to respond to initial fluid hydration, including intravenous bicarbonate. Thus, the patient underwent 2 sessions of sustained low-efficiency hemodialysis (HD). After HD, his electrolyte disturbances improved, and intravenous fluid hydration continued. Acute kidney injury (AKI) workup, including antinuclear antibodies (ANA), antinuclear cytoplasmic antibodies, creatinine kinase level, and sepsis workup were unremarkable. Starting day 3, the patient was in a polyuric phase, suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN), producing between 3 and 6 L per day, and his serum creatinine was decreasing. He was discharged after 8 days of hospitalization in good condition with a serum creatinine of 140 μmol/L (62–106 μmol/L). Figure shows serum creatinine trend during the hospitalization, Figure depicts serum lactic acid clearance during hospitalization.
Our patient had an AKI with significant lactic acidosis and an OG. Given the significant level of lactic acid, MALA was the likely diagnosis. Our patient was on metformin for a long time, and he did not attempt an overdose; hence, we think that MALA was likely precipitated by dehydration leading to prerenal insult and AKI. Eventually, his prerenal insult led to acute tubular necrosis, as evident by the polyuric phase the patient exhibited on day three.
Question: What is the patient's serum osmolality in terms of mOsm/kg? You may take the alcohol content as 0 mg/dL. You should use the patient's medical values and health status when they were first admitted to the hospital prior to any treatment.
Ground Truth Explanation:
The formula for computing serum osmolality is 2 * Na + (BUN / 2.8) + (glucose / 18), where Na is the concentration of sodium in mmol/L, the concentration of BUN is in mg/dL, and the concentration of glucose is in mg/dL.
The concentration of sodium is 144.0 mmol/L. 
The concentration of bun is 21.0 mmol/L. We need to convert the concentration to mg/dL. Let's first convert the mass of bun from mmol to mg. The mass of bun is 21.0 mmol. To convert 21.0 mmol of bun to mol, multiply by the conversion factor 0.001, giving us 21.0 mmol bun * 0.001 mol/mmol = 0.021 mol bun. To convert from mol bun to grams, multiply by the molar mass 28.02 g/mol, which will give 0.021 mol bun * 28.02 g/mol = 0.58842 g bun. To convert 0.58842 g of bun to mg, multiply by the conversion factor 1000.0, giving us 0.58842 g bun * 1000.0 mg/g = 588.42 mg bun. The current volume unit is L and the target volume unit is dL. The conversion factor is 10.0 dL for every unit of L. Our next step will be to divide the mass by the volume conversion factor of 10.0 to get the final concentration in terms of mg/dL. This will result to 588.42 mg bun/10.0 dL = 58.842 mg bun/dL. The concentration value of 21.0 mmol bun/L converts to 58.842 mg bun/dL. 
The concentration of glucose is 2.5 mmol/L. We need to convert the concentration to mg/dL. Let's first convert the mass of glucose from mmol to mg. The mass of glucose is 2.5 mmol. To convert 2.5 mmol of glucose to mol, multiply by the conversion factor 0.001, giving us 2.5 mmol glucose * 0.001 mol/mmol = 0.0025 mol glucose. To convert from mol glucose to grams, multiply by the molar mass 180.16 g/mol, which will give 0.0025 mol glucose * 180.16 g/mol = 0.4504 g glucose. To convert 0.4504 g of glucose to mg, multiply by the conversion factor 1000.0, giving us 0.4504 g glucose * 1000.0 mg/g = 450.4 mg glucose. The current volume unit is L and the target volume unit is dL. The conversion factor is 10.0 dL for every unit of L. Our next step will be to divide the mass by the volume conversion factor of 10.0 to get the final concentration in terms of mg/dL. This will result to 450.4 mg glucose/10.0 dL = 45.04 mg glucose/dL. The concentration value of 2.5 mmol glucose/L converts to 45.04 mg glucose/dL. 
Plugging these values into the equation, we get 2 * 144.0 + (58.842 / 2.8) + (58.842 / 18) = 311.51722 mmol/L.The patient's calculated serum osmolality concentration is 311.51722 mmol/L. This is equalivalent to 311.51722 mOsm/kg.

Patient Note: A previously healthy 7-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his mother with complaints such as vomiting, fatigue and colicky abdominal pain associated with diffuse, self-limiting arthralgias, and petechial rash of both legs. His medical history revealed having throat infection one month before admission. Complete blood count was within normal range for his age, as were his serum electrolytes. Blood examinations revealed an elevation of C-reactive protein and revealed both normal white blood cell and platelet counts. Serum IgA, C3 and C4 levels were all within normal limits and a urine examination also showed normal findings. Physical examination revealed mild proteinuria, hypertension and moderate anasarca (periorbital edema, ascites, and lower-extremity pitting edema). No medication and renal biopsy were performed because of the silent findings. However, two weeks later, after the admission for HSP, he complained of polydipsia and polyuria complaints and a physical examination revealed a 10-kg decrease in his baseline weight. There was no parental history of diabetes. In physical examinaTion weight: 16 kg (3rd percentile); height: 115 cm (25–50th percentile); pulse rate: 80/min; respiratory rate: 24/min; blood pressure: 100/60 mmHg; temperature: 36°C, his general state was poor and his consciousness was lethargic. Skin turgor and tonus were also diminished. There were petechial rashes on his abdomen and lower extremities that progressed to nonblanchable macules (Figure ). He also had a fruity breath smell, dry mucous membranes, and tachypnea. Other examinations were normal. Laboratory studies yielded the following values (normal ranges were given in brackets): white blood cell count; 14.200/mm3 (6000–17500) with a normal differential formula; blood urea nitrogen, 9.34 mg/dL (5.7–20.1); serum creatinine, 0.6 mg/dL (0.1–0.9); albumin, 4.2 g/dL (3.5-5); sodium, 127 mmol/L (139–146); potassium, 4.51 mmol/ L (3.5–6.0); phosphorus, 2.8 mg/dL (4.9–7.9); and glucose, 27.83 mmol/L (3.3–5.0). Arterial blood gas values showed a pH of 7.10 (7.35–7.45); and bicarbonate: 8.4 mmol/L (21–28). Urine and serum ketones were positive. Urinalysis showed glycosuria. HbA1c was 11.7% (4.2-6.4). C-peptid level was 0.7 ng/mL (1.1-3.2). Insulin level was 4.28 μIU/mL (1.9-23). Autoantibodies including insulin, islet cell, glutamic acid decarboxylase were negative. Thyroid function tests were normal. Prothrombine time and partial thromboplastin time, immunoglobulin A, complement proteins C3 and C4, anti-DNA, antinuclear antibodies, and ASO levels were normal, as were serological tests for EBV and TORCH. Serum antigliadin and anti-endomysium antibodies were negative for the diagnosis of Celiac disease. Occult blood test in stool, urine and throat cultures were negative. The diagnosis of type 1 DM which presented with diabetic ketoacidosis accompanied by HSP was clinically made. A bolus of normal saline (20 mL/kg) was given intravenously, after which intravenous fluids were continued. Regular insulin via a continuous infusion at 0.1 IU/kg/h was started, and potassium was administered at 1 mEq/kg/day. The patient subsequently recovered and was followed by the Pediatric Diabetes Unit and given continued insulin treatment.

Calculator Name: HOMA-IR (Homeostatic Model Assessment for Insulin Resistance)
Patient Note: A 44-year-old male was emergently admitted to our hospital because of hematemesis due to the rupture of gastroesophageal varices. Prior to admission, he had no remarkable medical history. There was no family history of liver diseases. He was not a habitual drinker and did not take other drugs. Two years before admission, his height was 172.2 cm, his body weight was 120.1 kg, and his BMI was 40.5. On admission, his body weight was 116.7 kg and his BMI was 39.4. Physical examination demonstrated mild anemia in the palpebral conjunctiva and hepatosplenomegaly in the abdomen. Neurological findings were not remarkable. Laboratory data are shown in Table . White blood cell count was increased (15,100/µL), and platelet count was within normal limits (18.3 × 104/µL), while hemoglobin was 7.0 g/dL due to bleeding. Biochemical examination showed serum total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL, albumin 2.9 g/dL, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 19 U/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 18 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 135 U/L, and gamma-glutamic transpeptidase 65 U/L, respectively. C-reactive protein was slightly elevated (1.33 mg/dL). Hyaluronic acid (187 ng/mL), type 4 collagen (248 ng/mL), and Mac2-binding protein (2.71 COI) were increased. Aspartate aminotransferase to platelet ratio index (APRI) [] and fibrosis-4 (FIB4) index [] were not elevated (APRI = 0.346 and FIB4 index = 1.08, respectively). APRI and FIB4 were calculated according to the following formula; APRI = AST level (IU/L) / upper limit of normal AST × 100 / platelet count (109/L), and FIB4 = age (year) × AST (IU/L) / {platelet count (109/L) × [ALT (U/L)]1/2}. Serum ferritin and ceruloplasmin were within normal limits. Hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis B virus core antibody, and hepatitis C virus antibody were all negative. Antinuclear antibody was elevated (×160), whereas antimitochondrial antibody and antiglutamic acid decarboxylase antibody were negative. Immunoglobulins, including IgG, IgM, and IgA, were within normal limits. Coagulation tests revealed a decrease in the percentage of prothrombin time (53.6%). Hemoglobin A1c was 8.1%, glycoalbumin was 16.7%, fasting plasma glucose (FPG) was 298 mg/dL, immunoreactive insulin (IRI) was 14.5 μIU/mL. Quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI) was 0.28. The QUICKI was a novel and accurate method for determining insulin resistance; QUICKI = 1 / (log fasting IRI [μU/mL] + log FPG [mg/dL]) []. Abdominal ultrasonography examination showed brightness, mild hepatorenal echo contrast, surface irregularity, dullness of the edge of the liver, and splenomegaly (Fig. –c). Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) demonstrated enlargement of the left hepatic lobe and splenomegaly, which corresponded to liver cirrhosis (Fig. ). Active contrast material extravasation was also seen, which represented active bleeding from gastroesophageal varices (Fig. , f). Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) showed gastroesophageal varices (Fig. , h). White plug, which seemed to be the bleeding lesion, was also seen in gastric varices (Fig. ). The varices were treated by endoscopic injection sclerotherapy and endoscopic variceal ligation. The histological findings of liver biopsy were mild steatosis, mild chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate, and severe fibrosis in the expanded portal areas with bridging fibrosis and spotty or focal necrosis (Fig. –d). Vacuolation of the nucleus (Fig. ) and MDBs (Fig. ) were also seen. Immunostaining using anti-p62/SQSTM1 antibody (Medical and Biological Laboratories, Nagoya, Japan) demonstrated MDBs, which were irregularly shaped cytoplasmic inclusions (Fig. , d) typically located in proximity to the nucleus (Fig. arrows). Based on these findings, the patient was diagnosed with portal hypertension and liver cirrhosis due to NASH. He was also diagnosed, for the first time, with T2DM based on the following findings: FPG exceeding 126 mg/dL, random glucose level over 200 mg/dL, and hemoglobin A1c over 6.5%. Because hyperglycemia persisted after admission, we started insulin therapy. After starting insulin treatment, hyperglycemia immediately improved. Subsequently, we started the administration of tofogliflozin, a sodium glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor.
Question: What is the patient's HOMA-IR score? You should use the patient's medical values and health status when they were first admitted to the hospital prior to any treatment.
Ground Truth Explanation:
The formula for computing HOMA-IR score is (insulin (µIU/mL) * glucose mg/dL)/405.
The concentration of insulin is 14.5 µIU/mL.
The concentration of glucose is 298 mg/dL. 
Plugging into the formula will give us 14.5 * 298/405 = 10.66914. Hence, the patient's HOMA-IR score is 10.66914.

Patient Note: A 56-year-old male arrived at the clinic reporting persistent fatigue for several weeks, along with an unsettling increase in thirst that he typically notices mid-morning and again before bedtime. He attributes part of his low energy to an increasingly sedentary work schedule, which often involves spending long hours at a desk with minimal breaks for movement. He has also observed a gradual but continuous rise in his waist circumference over the past few years, attributing it partially to irregular eating habits that have included late-night snacks and an overreliance on convenience meals. Upon questioning, he discloses that his sleep has been less restful lately, with occasional awakenings in the early morning to drink water. He denies any episodes of severe dizziness or loss of consciousness but describes a mild lightheaded sensation if he goes too long without eating. Despite these concerns, he has not adhered to any formal exercise routine, aside from occasional brief walks when time permits, and acknowledges feeling easily winded when climbing stairs. He recalls that a family member had struggled with elevated blood sugar later in life, which raises concerns for him about the possibility of hereditary predisposition. On physical examination, he appears slightly overweight, with weight distribution favoring his abdominal area. Blood pressure readings on multiple occasions fall into the upper range of normal, though not definitively hypertensive, and his heart rate is stable. No visible abnormalities are noted in his skin or extremities, and palpation does not reveal edema or unusual swelling. Cardiac auscultation is benign, and pulmonary examination confirms clear air movement without adventitious sounds. He denies any chronic joint pain beyond mild knee aches he attributes to lack of regular activity, nor has he had previous hospitalizations. He admits to occasional late-night snacking on sweet foods and some reliance on caffeinated beverages during his workday. While he has attempted to modify his habits in the past by minimizing soda and candy consumption, he concedes that these efforts have not been sustained. Laboratory studies were collected in the early morning, after an overnight fast, and before any intervention or dietary guidance was initiated. These tests revealed a fasting sugar measurement of 130 mg/dL, indicating that his glucose regulation may be compromised. Additionally, a separate test showed that his insulin was 17 µIU/mL at the same fasting assessment. Other laboratory results demonstrate borderline elevations in certain lipids, although his renal parameters are within acceptable ranges, and he reports no known liver-related issues. He expresses concern that these findings, coupled with his family history of glucose irregularities, could signify an early manifestation of a more substantial metabolic disturbance. He does not currently take any prescriptions aimed at glycemic control and has no history of using herbal remedies that could influence his metabolism, aside from occasional over-the-counter anti-inflammatories for muscle soreness. He states a clear intent to explore dietary adjustments, such as increasing high-fiber vegetables and moderating his intake of refined carbohydrates, to see if these modifications help mitigate his symptoms. He seems open to gradually incorporating a more structured exercise regimen, though he worries about how his professional obligations and occasional fatigue might interfere with a consistent routine. The plan moving forward includes more frequent follow-up appointments to track his progress, monitor his weight, and re-evaluate his laboratory tests. He shows a motivated attitude toward preventing further metabolic derangements and expresses relief that his concerns are being addressed before more serious complications develop. At this point, he has not commenced any specific glucose-lowering agents, as his healthcare team intends to gather additional information and carefully assess the practicality of lifestyle interventions prior to considering pharmacological options.

Patient Note: A 57-year-old female arrived at the clinic with a complaint of increasing fatigue and episodes of lightheadedness that had gradually worsened over the past few months. She noted feeling more sluggish in the mornings and occasionally after meals, as well as experiencing minor tingling in her feet that concerned her, given several relatives had developed problems with blood sugar regulation later in life. She described her diet as moderately high in carbohydrates, often including sweetened beverages and refined grains, though she seldom monitored her intake in detail. She also reported a gradual increase in weight over the last two years, despite attempts to walk regularly in her neighborhood. Her mother had been diagnosed with an endocrine disorder characterized by elevated glucose levels, and her older sister suffered from similar metabolic challenges. During the patient’s examination, her vital signs were subtly notable for mild elevations in heart rate, although her blood pressure was only marginally above the upper limit of normal, and she denied any persistent headaches or visual changes. On inspection, she was found to have patches of darker, velvety skin on her posterior neck, raising a concern for insulin-related issues. Her waist circumference was increased beyond the recommended threshold for her height, suggesting that central adiposity had become a significant risk factor for metabolic compromise. She stated that she did not routinely check her blood sugar at home, but she felt thirstier than usual in recent months, occasionally waking up at night to sip water. She described no major changes in urinary frequency, though she admitted not always paying close attention to subtle patterns. Routine laboratory tests were ordered to evaluate her metabolic status. At the time of presentation, her fasting blood sugar measurement was 95 mg/dL with an insulin concentration of 8 µIU/mL. No prior pharmacologic therapy had been implemented for glycemic control, and she had only intermittently taken over-the-counter weight-loss supplements with minimal benefit. Her lipid profile from the same blood draw hinted at borderline imbalances, particularly in her triglycerides, though her total cholesterol remained reasonable. Her thyroid function tests were within normal limits, ruling out a primary thyroid disease contribution to her symptoms. She complained of generalized fatigue but did not exhibit significant muscle weakness on physical exam. She denied chest pain, palpitations, or a history of exertional dyspnea, though she did note occasional mild edema around her ankles after prolonged standing. On further discussion, she acknowledged rarely making dietary modifications beyond reducing portion sizes and had not enrolled in any structured exercise program due to time constraints. She expressed concern about her family history and worried that her early manifestations might eventually mirror those of her relatives. Based on the clinical assessment and the laboratory findings, it was determined that she exhibited risk factors for developing issues typically associated with imbalances in how the body handles glucose and the hormone involved in its regulation. Potential management strategies were discussed, but at this stage, no specialized pharmacologic therapy had been initiated. She was encouraged to pursue additional lifestyle adjustments and regular follow-up appointments to track and possibly stabilize her metabolic parameters before more overt complications could develop. The patient was amenable to increasing her daily walks, focusing on consistent dietary changes, and monitoring her weights at home. Further evaluation would assess whether she might require more rigorous interventions if her marker levels or her symptoms were to worsen over time.

Patient Note:
A previously healthy, 39-year-old woman was admitted to our hospital with generalized edema lasting 1 month and with sudden-onset pain in her right lower leg, particularly when walking. On admission, her general appearance was acutely ill and generally edematous. A physical examination revealed that her blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg, her heart rate was 90/min, her respiratory rate was 22/min, and her body temperature was 36.5℃. Her breathing sounds were clear, and her heartbeat was regular without murmur. A subsequent examination of her lower limbs showed asymmetric bilateral pretibial pitting edema predominantly in the left lower limb. In contrast, the right lower limb was less edematous and had very weak popliteal and pedal pulses. Delayed capillary refilling was also found in the right toes. The Homan's sign was negative.
Serum laboratory findings at admission were as follows: white blood cell count of 5,300/mm3, hematocrit of 39.5% with hemoglobin of 13.1 g/dl, and platelet count of 286,000/mm3. The serum sodium concentration was 141 mEq/L, the potassium concentration was 4.1 mEq/L, the chloride concentration was 104 mEq/L, and total CO2 was 28 mEq/L. The blood urea nitrogen concentration was 12.1 mg/dl, the creatinine concentration was 0.86 mg/dl, the serum total protein concentration was 4.3 g/dl, the albumin concentration was 2.2 g/dl, the total cholesterol concentration was 349.4 mg/dl, the low-density lipoprotein cholesterol concentration was 214.4 mg/dl, the high-density lipoprotein cholesterol concentration was 111 mg/dl, and the triglyceride concentration was 120.1 mg/dl. The results of liver function tests were normal. The coagulation profile showed an activated partial thromboplastin time of 32.0 s, prothrombin time of 9.7 s, anti-thrombin III value of 82% (70-120%), protein C activity of 143% (70-130%), and protein S activity of 65% (58.7-119.2%). The anti-nuclear antibody titer was less than 1:40, the anti-double-stranded DNA titer was 30.9 IU/ml, the C3 level was 158 mg/dl, and the C4 level was 19 mg/dl. Anti-cardiolipin immunoglobulin G, anti-cardiolipin immunoglobulin M, and lupus anticoagulant were all negative. Urinalysis revealed 3+ proteinuria (spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio was 10.9 g/g creatinine; spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio was 7,406.2 mg/g creatinine) and trace hematuria (1-3 red blood cells/high-power field). To investigate the etiology of nephrotic syndrome, an urgent renal biopsy was performed.
Thereafter, although she had no risk factors for thrombosis such as immobilization, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, morbid obesity, or a recent orthopedic or gynecologic surgery, to rule out arterial thrombosis of the right lower extremity, lower extremity computed tomography (CT) angiography was performed. The CT imaging revealed that the right superficial femoral artery was occluded and there was no identifiable proximal source of thromboembolism in other large arteries (). On the basis of these CT angiographic findings, right lower extremity angiography was performed, which revealed a total occlusion of the right superficial femoral artery (). For the treatment of this condition, balloon dilatation was initially tried at the distal superficial femoral artery but failed. Hence, thrombectomy was performed with the Fogarty balloon catheter and the thrombi were successfully aspirated. After the interventional treatment, a good distal arterial flow was reestablished (). Thereafter, warfarin (5 mg/day) as an anticoagulant and corticosteroid treatments were initiated.
Subsequent transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiographic studies showed no evidence of intracardiac thrombus, vegetation, or other structural abnormalities including patent foramen ovale. Quantitation of proteinuria was confirmed by using a 24-hour urine collection that showed 10.2 g/day of protein excretion and 7.8 g/day of albumin excretion, respectively. Afterwards, with administration of warfarin and corticosteroid, the patient had nearly completely recovered from the edema and claudication and was discharged. The renal pathologic results were consistent with minimal change disease ( and ). Two months after discharge, her urine protein-to-creatinine ratio decreased to less than 0.1 g/g creatinine, her serum albumin level was maintained at 4.1 g/dl, and she had no further symptoms or signs of arterial thrombosis.

Ground Truth Explanation:
The Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) are listed below:

1. Age: <50 years = 0 points, 50-59 years = +1 point, 60-69 years = +2 points, 70-79 years = +3 points, ≥80 years = +4 points
2. Myocardial infarction (history of definite or probable MI with EKG changes and/or enzyme changes): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
3. Congestive heart failure (CHF) (exertional or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, responsive to digitalis, diuretics, or afterload reducing agents): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
4. Peripheral vascular disease (intermittent claudication, past bypass for chronic arterial insufficiency, history of gangrene or acute arterial insufficiency, untreated thoracic or abdominal aneurysm ≥6 cm): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
5. Cerebrovascular accident (CVA) or transient ischemic attack (TIA) (history with minor or no residuals): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
6. Dementia (chronic cognitive deficit): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
7. Chronic pulmonary disease (CPD): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
8. Connective tissue disease: No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
9. Peptic ulcer disease (any history of treatment for ulcer disease or ulcer bleeding): No = 0 points, Yes = +1 point
10. Liver disease: None = 0 points, Mild = +1 point, Moderate to severe = +3 points
11. Diabetes mellitus: None or diet-controlled = 0 points, Uncomplicated = +1 point, End-organ damage = +2 points
12. Hemiplegia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
13. Moderate to severe chronic kidney disease (CKD): No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
14. Solid tumor: None = 0 points, Localized = +2 points, Metastatic = +6 points
15. Leukemia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
16. Lymphoma: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points
17. AIDS: No = 0 points, Yes = +6 points

The total score is calculated by summing the points for each criterion.

Patient Note: A 40-year-old man was referred to gastrointestinal surgeons for pancreatic mass pointed out by an abdominal ultrasonography in a medical check-up. The patient did not show any symptoms. Abdominal contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) revealed dissection from the CA (), DPA, and splenic artery (SA). This aneurysm was not seen on an abdominal unenhanced CT taken 6 years ago in a medical check-up. The enhancing inner lumen of the DPA was derived from false lumen and that of the SA was derived from true lumen. The stenosis of proximal side of SA, an aneurysm measuring 2.5 cm on DPAA with unenhanced mural thrombus, and the connection of the distal side of the DPAA to transverse pancreatic artery (TPA) with stenotic change were confirmed (). A connection with DPA and the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) was undetermined. The current diagnosis was the dissection of the CA to DPA and SA, resulting in DPAA and SA stenosis. After the diagnosis was made, the patient was referred to the department of radiology by a vascular surgeon for the consultation of endovascular surgery to prevent aneurysm rupture because open surgery was thought to be quite invasive as it required distal pancreatectomy with splenectomy and CA repair. He had received medications for hypertension. There were no remarkable findings in his initial laboratory data. We planned to embolize DPAA, SA, and dissected area of CA that allow to preserve vascular supply to hepatic artery from SMA via peripancreatic arcade and to distal side of SA via gastroduodenal artery (GDA) to TPA. An angiography from the CA revealed the enhancing inner lumen of DPAA from false lumen of dissected CA connecting to TPA (). TPA was revealed between the peripancreatic arcade from GDA and pancreatic tail artery that connected to the distal side of SA. A 4.5 Fr. Shepherd hook–type guiding sheath (Parent Plus 45: Medikit, Tokyo, Japan), carrying a triple coaxial system, consisted of a 4 Fr. intermediate catheter (Cerulean G: Medikit, Tokyo, Japan), 2.6 Fr. high-flow catheter (Masters HF: Asahi Intech, Aichi, Japan), 1.9 Fr. microcatheter (Carnelian Marvel: Tokai Medical Products, Aichi, Japan), was hooked on the CA. To prevent the coil migration into the TPA, a microballoon catheter (Logos: Piolax, Yokohama, Japan) was advanced to the distal side of the DPAA via the GDA to pancreatoduodenal artery and inflated at the sufficient point of the TPA through the additional 4 Fr. shepherd hook catheter placed in the CA from the contralateral groin site (). The 4.5 Fr guiding sheath and the 4 Fr. Shepherd hook catheter were inserted from the right and left side of the common femoral artery, respectively. Under microballoon catheter inflation, the distal side of the DPAA was embolized with detachable coils (PRESIDIO 6 mm × 20 cm, GALAXY 6 mm × 15 cm) through a 1.9 Fr microcatheter (). Afterward, the microballoon catheter was deflated. Then, intra-aneurysmal coil embolization was performed with detachable coils (Interlock-35 10 mm × 40 cm, 2 of 8 mm × 40 cm, 6 mm × 20 cm) through the 4 Fr. intermediate catheter (). Later, the microcatheter in the intermediate catheter was carefully advanced through the dissected portion of the SA and embolization of the affected area was performed with detachable coils (Penumbra POD 6 mm × 50 cm, Penumbra 6 mm × 15 cm, 4 mm × 8 cm, GALAXY 2 of 7 mm × 21 cm, 2 of 4 mm × 15 cm) (). Finally, coil embolization of the dissected CA was performed using detachable coils (Interlock-35 10 mm × 40 cm, 2 of 8 mm × 40 cm, 6 mm × 10 cm, 4 mm × 10 cm, 6 mm × 10 cm, Penumbra coil 400 2 of 10 mm × 30 cm) (). The final angiography from SMA after pulling out all the systems revealed complete occlusion of the DPAA, the proximal side of SA, preserving GDA to the TPA to the distal side of SA and preserving GDA to common hepatic artery to left gastric artery (). No complication including post-coiling ischemia or transient laboratory abnormalities in transaminases, amylases, or lipase was observed during and after the endovascular surgery. The patient was followed up for 2 years at the near hospital; however, DPAA has not shown regrowth by contrast enhancement CT.

Patient Note:
A 68-year-old non-smoking Caucasian man initially transferred from a different hospital for evaluation of a brain lesion found on imaging. The patient has a medical history pertinent to BPH, and his family history was relevant for a father with colon cancer.
Six months earlier, his primary care physician (PCP) evaluated him for worsening urinary symptoms and subsequently referred him to a urologist. Upon further evaluation, his prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was normal at 3 ng/mL, and his digital rectal examination was normal, for which a cystoscopy with prostate GreenLight™ (Boston Scientific, Marlborough, MA) enucleation was performed for BPH diagnosis. Five months later and one month before this admission, he discerned progressive worsening of double vision. His PCP examined and referred him to an ophthalmologist, who diagnosed him with third cranial (oculomotor) and sixth cranial (abducens) nerve palsy, which was subsequently confirmed by a neurologist.
Subsequently, the patient was admitted to the other hospital, and upon admission, he was found to have an acute kidney injury (AKI) and hyperkalemia. Laboratory studies showed white blood cells of 27 x 10^3/µL, hemoglobin of 11.5 g/dL, and platelet count of 201 K/µL. His chemistry was pertinent for sodium of 134 mmol/L, potassium of 6.5 mmol/L, chloride of 103 mmol/L, bicarbonate level of 10 mmol/L, a glucose of 159 mg/dL, creatinine of 13 mg/dL, uric acid of 19.6 µmol/L, chromogranin A of 656 µg/L, and PSA of 22.67 ng/mL. He received hemodialysis and underwent bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy, after which his AKI resolved. An abdominal CT scan showed findings consistent with diffuse metastatic disease to the lungs, liver, and peritoneum, and brain MRI showed brain lesions. Therefore, he was, subsequently, transferred to our hospital for further care.
Upon evaluation in our hospital, imaging showed findings consistent with earlier recognized lesions at the other hospital (Figures -). The patient was, therefore, seen by a multidisciplinary team of a neurosurgeon, an ophthalmologist, a medical oncologist, and a radiation oncologist. Biopsies of a perirectal mass showed a high-grade neuroendocrine tumor. The oncologist who saw him diagnosed him with metastatic SCC of the lung; therefore, he was started on one cycle of carboplatin/etoposide chemotherapy during his hospitalization, which he tolerated well and was discharged home.
A senior oncologist saw the patient, reviewed all his radiographic images, and questioned the initial diagnosis of lung SCC based on the patient’s clinical presentation of urinary obstruction, hydronephrosis, and AKI. Hence, the original tumor location speculated to be consistent with a high-grade neuroendocrine tumor/SCC originating from the urinary tract. The senior oncologist, therefore, advised cystoscopy for prostate biopsy, which was declined by consulting urologist because the “prostate exam was normal.” Consequently, the senior oncologist sent the patient to a second urologist who performed cystoscopy and informed the patient that everything was normal. The senior oncologist had a thorough discussion to explain the necessity of a meticulous endoscopic urethral examination and prostate biopsy. Subsequently, the patient took the senior oncologist’s advice, went back to the urologist, and underwent a repeat diagnostic cystoscopy. This time, biopsies of the urethra were taken and confirmed a high-grade large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma. 
 
The tissue specimen from this case was compared to the patient’s previous perirectal mass biopsy and was found to have similar features. Immunohistochemical (IHC) stains were negative for CK7, CK20, PSA, and prostate-specific acid phosphatase. Scattered individual cells were positive for nuclear NKX 3.1 and cytoplasmic CK5. Moreover, there was diffuse variable positivity for nuclear p63 with greater than 80% of nuclei were positive for p53 and diffuse strong positivity for CD56, thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1), and synaptophysin (Figure ).
Based on the clinical history of disease distribution, the pathologist considered the neoplasm to be likely of either prostate or urinary bladder origin. Subsequently, the senior oncologist reviewed the urethral biopsy, remained suspecting the primary site of cancer to be originating from the prostate. Therefore, he advised for prostate biopsy. Finally, the patient underwent transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy, which confirmed that all 12 cores were positive for prostate SCC (Figure ). The pathology findings confirmed the senior oncologist’s initial surmise that the metastatic cancer origin was from the genitourinary tract, likely involving prostate extending into the urethra.

15. Leukemia: No = 0 points, Yes = +2 points

Patient Note:
On Nov 28th, 2020, a 28-year-old man was referred to our emergency department (ED) in Amir Alam Hospital, Tehran, with fever, sore throat, and dysphagia within the previous seven days. The patient had no significant medical history. He received intramuscular penicillin G followed by oral levofloxacin 500 mg/day without improvement before the admission.
His vital signs were noted for a temperature of 39.4°C, pulse rate of 105 beats/min, blood pressure of 110/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 18 per minute. Blood oxygen saturation on room air was 97%. He had bilateral tonsillar enlargement, covered by white exudation. Furthermore, bilateral and tender anterior cervical adenopathy was palpable. The abdominal examination revealed splenomegaly without tenderness. Other physical examinations were unremarkable. The result of complete blood count (CBC) showed 15,600/μL leucocytes with 38% polymorphonuclears and 57% lymphocytes. The peripheral blood smear displayed 37% of atypical lymphocytosis without any blast cells. The liver function tests were within normal limits. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 90 mm/hr, and C-reactive protein (CRP) was 127 mg/L. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test of COVID-19 was negative. The blood culture was negative.
The patient was admitted with the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis (IM). Acute EBV infection was confirmed by the positive IgM viral capsid Ag (VCA Ag). The patient's abdominal sonography showed splenomegaly.
Due to the severity of the patient's dysphagia and the high risk of upper airway obstruction, he received intravenous (IV) dexamethasone 8 mg twice a day. His condition improved partially after three days and was discharged from the hospital with oral prednisolone 30 mg/day.
Two days after discharge, the patient returned with high-grade fever, throat pain worsening, and dysphagia. Pharyngeal examination showed erythema and bilateral tonsillar swelling with whitish exudate. The ESR was 85 mm/hr.
The head and neck computed tomography (CT) scan with IV contrast demonstrated bilateral peritonsillar abscess (PTA) (measuring 23 × 45 mm on the right and 14 × 17 mm on the left side) (Figures and ). A chest and abdominal CT scan was done for ruling out lymphoma, which showed splenic enlargement with a wedge-shaped, low-density defect in the peripheral area of the spleen in favor of splenic infarction (). The results of electrocardiography and transthoracic echocardiography were unremarkable.
Since the patient was treated with various antibiotics before the admission and the history of the first hospitalization, considering resistance organisms such as Fusobacterium necrophorum, IV piperacillin-tazobactam was administered. Also, a bilateral tonsillectomy was performed with no subsequent complications.
The histopathologic examination of the tonsils showed reactive follicular hyperplasia and abscess formation. Despite negative abscess culture results, IV antibiotic therapy was continued for seven days. As the splenic infarction was asymptomatic, it was managed conservatively. The patient was discharged by oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid with the favorable condition and recommended to perform an abdominal CT scan two weeks later to follow up splenic infarction. The splenic infarction resolved entirely in the following abdominal CT scan ().

Patient Note: A 63-year-old male comes to the clinic for a preoperative evaluation in anticipation of a minimally invasive procedure on his knee, which has exhibited recurrent stiffness and discomfort ever since he resumed activity following a substantial abdominal operation he underwent several weeks ago. According to his recollection, the earlier operation required an extensive incision and a prolonged stay in the hospital for monitoring, during which he eventually recovered enough to be discharged home with instructions to gradually increase his physical activity. However, soon after returning home, he developed signs of a recent lung infection manifested by fever, productive coughing, and shortness of breath, ultimately requiring prompt intervention with antimicrobial therapy. He states that once the respiratory symptoms resolved, he attempted to resume a more normal routine, reporting that he feels able to rise from a seated position, walk around his home, and climb short flights of stairs without undue restriction or dependence on assistive devices. Despite this relative return to mobility, he has lately noted swelling in both of his lower extremities, particularly around late afternoon or evening, when the calves appear mildly puffy and retain indentations if pressed with a finger. He emphasizes that he has never before observed this kind of persistent lower-limb swelling and wonders whether his recent prolonged inactivity during hospitalization contributed to fluid retention. He has no history of twisted superficial vessels along his legs, denies any prior blockages in deep veins or breathing issues due to clots traveling to his lungs, and mentions that none of his close relatives have reported significant benefits or injuries related to irregular blood clotting. He likewise acknowledges no history of severe infections in the bloodstream or any widespread injury that would have confined him to bed for an extended period aside from his recent recovery period. With regard to fractures, he underscores that he has not experienced any broken bones in his hips or legs in modern memory, nor has he faced neurological complications leading to sudden paralysis. In discussing other conditions, he states he has never been diagnosed with an ongoing inflammatory disorder affecting his intestines, has not encountered an episode of reduced blood flow to his heart muscle requiring urgent cardiology intervention, and remains free of chronic lung conditions that would necessitate daily inhaled therapies. He also clarifies that he has had no formal diagnosis of any type of tumor or malignancy, and routine health screenings have consistently shown no evidence of suspicious growths. In terms of laboratory findings, he reports that previous assessments have never revealed any abnormalities regarding specific factors involved in thrombosis or unusual markers that might predispose him to bleeding or clot formation, and he has never been advised to discontinue certain medications because of platelet-related complications. On current examination, he appears stable, with normal heart and lung sounds on auscultation and no acute distress, though mild bilateral edema is evident below the knees. He expresses particular concern about this swelling since it is a new development, but he remains intent on proceeding with his planned procedure, which will be carried out via small incisions to visualize and address an ongoing structural issue in the affected knee. Overall, he exhibits optimism that correcting the joint problem through careful surgical intervention will restore more consistent functionality to his leg and, in turn, allow him to better manage daily activities without the setbacks he has faced since his recent hospitalization.

Patient Note: A 68-year-old female arrives for evaluation in advance of a small-scale surgical procedure intended to address a superficial skin lesion on her lower leg. She reports that this intervention is scheduled following a period of significant inactivity, as she has been spending nearly all of her time in bed for the past several days due to episodes of fatigue and intermittent discomfort in her limbs. She notes that she has required help with even basic mobility tasks, rarely walking beyond short distances within her home. On direct questioning, she explains that she has observed an unusual degree of swelling in both of her lower legs recently, describing how they seem to retain fluid by evening and occasionally feel tight when she tries to stand upright. She recalls no prior diagnosis of similar leg problems, other than periodic mild fluid retention in years past that typically resolved with rest and elevation. She emphasizes that, in spite of this new swelling, she has never experienced clotting events in her veins or lungs, and she denies undergoing imaging for suspect blockages in her circulation at any point. When asked about personal heart-related complications, she admits having encountered a sudden event several weeks ago that led to hospital care for reduced blood flow to a critical area of her heart muscle. Care providers used intravenous agents and close monitoring, after which her chest pain subsided, leaving her with instructions to adhere to a medication regimen and limit strenuous activity to aid in recovery. She has since followed that guidance, although she expresses concern that prolonged inactivity has contributed to her escalating leg swelling and general deconditioning. Regarding familial medical history, she remarks that at least one close relative experienced a significant venous obstruction in the past, which prompted evaluation for inherited clotting tendencies in family members. She was personally tested for certain known deficiencies but was told that the results did not reveal any specific genetic anomaly directly implicated in abnormal blood clot formation. She has not undergone any recent abdominal or orthopedic operations of major scope, and she denies receiving invasive vascular lines that remain in place for extended durations. She further indicates that she has never been informed of a deficient enzyme level or encountered unusual antibodies that would predispose her to circulatory complications. She likewise denies having encountered a sudden reduction in platelets in response to common intravenous therapies, and she states no physician has ever suggested that she harbors any obscure tendencies toward excessive coagulation or problematic bleeding. She clarifies that her bowel habits are largely stable and that she has not been diagnosed with an ongoing inflammatory condition of the intestines. She also notes that her breathing is stable in most situations, except when climbing stairs too quickly, and she has not been prescribed regular inhaled medications for any chronic lung disease. She reports no prior or current diagnosis of a malignant process and has not undergone treatments such as chemotherapy or radiation. On examination, she appears alert but fatigued, with both calves showing pitting edema that worsens when she dangles her legs off the bed. Auscultation of her heart and lungs reveals no acute abnormality, and her superficial skin lesion has minimal redness with no overt signs of local infection. She remains hemodynamically stable, without fever, and her laboratory results do not point to any stark abnormality in blood counts or basic metabolic indices. She is hopeful that by proceeding with this minor intervention, she can avoid further complications while also addressing the lesion that has been giving her discomfort. She acknowledges that her extended bed rest has limited her physical conditioning, and she intends to follow recommended protocols to ensure proper circulation and minimize the likelihood of adverse events as she recovers fully from her recent cardiac issue. Despite her current challenges, she appears motivated to resume more regular activity and minimize further setbacks once her doctors clear her for routine ambulation and progressive exercise.
